A recent study by Deloitte Australia’s Tech Trends 2018 report, titled “Future of AI: The Promise of Artificial Intelligence,” and in collaboration with the Australian Computer Society (ACS), showed that AI adoption in Australia is expected to increase, especially among smaller companies due to lower barriers to entry.

The Deloitte study found that 48 per cent of smaller companies are currently working on AI and automation, with a further 42 per cent planning to do so. Seventeen per cent are not considering AI.

AI systems can analyze, learn, evaluate, and predict outcomes, and it has been proven to be more accurate with fewer errors than a human.

The future of AI is an area that holds immense possibility for humanity. It’s a field driven by curiosity, by a desire to know how the world works, and to apply that knowledge towards making a positive impact. At a time when uncertainty abounds—in a world with immense challenges such as climate change, poverty, conflict, and systemic inequality—AI is becoming an increasingly important tool for empowering communities and pushing the boundaries of what’s possible. It’s being deployed in countless applications, from healthcare and education to conservation and climate resilience, to name but a few.

But the future of AI isn’t just about the technology itself. Rather, it’s about how we, as a society, are able to shape and guide it in a way that benefits everyone and ensures it is fair, resilient, inclusive, and sustainable. It’s an ongoing conversation, a conversation that needs everyone’s input.

The future of AI is about how humans and machines can work together for the betterment of the world, an expert said during a panel discussion at the AIIA Symposium 2019 Thursday.

Aymeric Glauser, the chief executive of the company behind the chatbot Moneypenny, said he is a firm believer that AI technology can and should be used for the greater good.

“Artificial intelligence is at the very heart of how we do business, and one of our missions is to give humanity time back,” Glauser said during a panel discussion on AI's future with other experts from global tech companies.

“[AI] shouldn't be for fun; it shouldn't be for vanity. It should be about building a better future for humanity,” he added.

Glauser said companies should be thinking about “democratizing data” to enable as many people as possible to access AI technology.

Bard builds on years of Google research and learning to bring contextual understanding, up-to-date information, and a fluid conversation style that you can engage with on a personal, conversational level. And with Bard, the company is reinventing the search experience by making it easier for you to discover precisely what you’re looking for.

The model is built on LaMDA (Language Model for Dialogue Applications), Google’s state-of-the-art conversational AI technology that was central to the plot of the film, "The Discovery," and served as inspiration for some of the features and capabilities you see in Bard.

The future of AI is bright, but we must be aware of the dangers as well. In recent years, we have seen rapid progress in AI, from self-driving cars and virtual assistants like Siri and Alexa to sophisticated robotics and machine learning systems. These advances have the potential to improve our lives in many ways, from making our daily tasks easier to solving complex problems in fields such as medicine and climate science.

However, it is also important to acknowledge the risks and challenges that come with AI. These include issues related to privacy, accountability, ethics, and the potential for AI systems to be used maliciously. We must therefore approach AI with a balanced and thoughtful perspective, one that recognizes both its potential benefits and its risks.

The future of AI is in the hands of humans. That’s the message AI leaders delivered at the Wall Street Journal’s Future of Everything Festival on Wednesday in New York.

In a panel discussion, four experts agreed that AI’s potential for humanity is endless when used properly but could be its own downfall if left unchecked.

IBM Watson CEO David Kenny said AI has the potential to eradicate diseases and solve global warming if the technology is used with the intention of making humanity better. However, it could have the opposite effect if AI is used for bad intentions.

“If we use the technology as it’s intended, it will save millions of lives and solve world problems,” said Kenny. “If we don’t, it can take away many millions of jobs. We have to decide which AI future we want to live through, and I think we have the power.”

We could be heading towards a world in which “the AI economy can deliver unprecedented gains and social benefits, such as those envisioned in science fiction”[1]. Or we could become dependent on an AI that may eventually surpass us in capabilities and that may turn on us. Or there could be various shades between. The implications include economic, social, ethical, and environmental. Many uncertainties therefore surround the development of AI, but the potential rewards are large, as are the risks. The future of AI is artificial intelligence (AI) that is not only learning from data, but also generating new data. This is known as generative AI, and it has the potential to revolutionize the way we interact with technology.

1. AI as a model: The most common AI models today are based on supervised learning, where the AI is trained on a dataset with labeled examples. The AI learns to make predictions or decisions based on this data. Generative AI, on the other hand, is an unsupervised learning model. Instead of being trained on a dataset of labeled examples, it generates new data that is similar to the data it was trained on. This can include generating images, text, music, or even complex models like deepfakes.
2. Data generation: One of the key advantages of generative AI is its ability to generate high-quality data in areas where data is scarce or difficult to collect. This can include generating synthetic data for training machine learning models,

## What is AI-as-a-Service?

AI-as-a-Service (AlaaS) refers to businesses providing AI-specific services to customers, instead of companies developing and executing AI projects in-house. The concept of AlaaS is built on the existing Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) model and is also often connected to the cloud. It means that AI applications can be used through cloud-based software, using a pay-per-use pricing model.

This service model enables companies—regardless of their size or resources—to incorporate AI tools without the need for significant upfront investment
